review_title: Nepotism and favoritism are priority one
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Orange Beach, AL
pros: Now offers remote work opportunities
cons: Nepotism, favoritism, incompetent people promoted, hard workers let go. It's all about who you know or are related to. If you don't play into the mentality that work is your family and should come first, then you're going to be passed over and looked down on. Pay is very low with little to no cost of living adjustments. I started out at $12 an hour and after almost 10 years haven't even reached $17 hr. They have now all but stopped giving raises since enrollments numbers have dropped. Company has been doing mass layoffs with zero notice to some who have worked with them for 10+ years. With csu loyalty only works one way. When it's performance review time you'll be told "no one's perfect" and scored lower on your review even though you're also told you're doing everything correctly. This score determines the amount of your raise. They're lowering your total score because according to them, no one is capable of that level of perfection deserving a whopping whole $0.50. This in my experience being the highest raise I have ever received. If you have issues with being told this and go to report it, the supervisor accused will immediately be told everything that you said and allowed to come confront you while you're trying to work. You'll be forced to meet together with another member of HR and the supervisor who has been reported will be allowed to decide the outcome of the dispute. Numerous issues with work flow and zero support from leadership who don't understand your job duties enough to even assist if they did want to.

review_title: Listen to your employees, not just senior management
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Orange Beach, AL
pros: Semi-casual, laid back work environment. Tuition discount allows employees to obtain a degree at a significantly reduced cost. I believe the company genuinely wants to improve lives through education, but they need help getting there.
cons: Many members of senior management are not qualified for the positions they hold; many other members of management do not have a degree. This makes it hard to respect the leaders in an educational environment without a degree. CSU does not provide relevant training to its employees. The training provided is provided by individuals not qualified to train on the topics. There is no follow through on initiatives and priorities change too often. Lots of politics. Senior management does not listen to employees. Often, the employees know the problem, and have a solution to the problem, but senior management either ignores the solution or presents the solution as his or her own and takes credit. Compensation was low, and many times way below industry standards. Many divisions employ staff members with a master's degree in their field, yet these individuals make very little (average 34-36,000). The HR department is a joke and keeps nothing confidential. Senior leaders often tell the story of coming from nothing, and then follow it up with information and details of their new, extravagant lives.

job_title: A Long-time Employee in Orange Beach, AL
pros: Exceptionally clean work environment - buildings and grounds are well-maintained;  Staff are provided better-than-average computer equipment, including dual monitors and up-to-date software to perform job functions;  assigned individual cubicles (not shared with other employees);  free unlimited coffee and filtered water;  five fully-equipped break rooms including an expansive vending machine/convenience store option for breaks/lunchtime;  generous vacation, personal time, paid birthday off and paid holidays, as well as additional paid days during Thanksgiving and Christmas.
cons: Nothing against the company itself but some staff (including members of the management team) are not appreciative of the benefits that CSU provides because they are from what I call the "entitlement age".  They often feel that they are entitled to be treated like Kings and Queens, even though they have only been in the workforce for a short period of time.  This causes strife within departments and it's difficult to maintain a positive attitude with all the complaining going on over unimportant issues.  People should be happy they have a job that pays decent wages and if they are not happy, they should move on to another company.

review_title: They can't keep anybody in the Corporate Development Department
job_title: Corporate Outreach in Orange Beach, AL
pros: I can't think of any!
cons: Take heed to what the others have said about this company. They can't keep anyone in the travel rep department. 2 other people have been released from the same department under the same person since 2013. (that's what happened to me,I moved there) I understand that Alabama is a right to work state but they just can't keep quality people over there that has common sense. Management don't ever seem to want to take responsibility for their actions and they think that you are suppose to take blame for everything not them. They will accuse you of things that are not true and fire you without a real reason!  If you are asked to come in for an interview do not go! From the VP down to the supervisors and even some of the employees are all uneducated idiots that call themselves running a department and don't know how to train, support, or lead their employees. The problem is management and unfortunately, the owners don't want to "clean house" and get rid of the bad eggs and get a new educated crew with experience running a real school. Instead they just want to get rid of the hard working people trying their best.

review_title: Columbia Southern University offers a unique experience that blends corporate business and education.
job_title: Department Manager in Orange Beach, AL
pros: Columbia Southern University has been on the forefront of online education for a decade. Their business models offers value in the form of online education, which promotes career advancement for the working adult. The University continues to grow in a flat market. Seemingly, there are endless opportunities for the company and individuals seeking employment. The environment and culture of the company are in the mid-high range. The President seeks to offer a family oriented, enjoyable working environment.
cons: Columbia Southern University has experienced growth beyond expectation. This factor caused a level of irrational decision making, resulting in continuous crisis mode as the rule and not the exception. This produces a stressful work environment that's not sustainable for most people. In addition, management is not as mature as they could be due to accelerated growth.

review_title: This Is not a school, it's a business call center
job_title: Advisor in Orange Beach, AL
pros: The daily food trucks were nice.
cons: When i stopped looking at this place as education and started looking at it as a business, it made more sense. This is a call center disguised as a school. The degrees are not worth the paper they are printed on, and when students call to discuss it, they have prepared talking points to deal with it. You are required to constantly be on the phone making calls. The students are treated like children and not adults. The leadership is incompetent and things change weekly. The answer to every question is 'It Depends'. You are to sit in your cubicle and work from 9am to 6pm and hope to be lucky enough to leave at 5pm with seniority. I would recommend not working at this place. The turnover rate is incredibly high. Once you're out of training, you see how things really are. It gets old very fast.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Orange Beach, AL
pros: Good benefits. Many good people trying to make a positive impact.
cons:
Columbia Southern University is a for-profit university. That, in itself, is a significant area to focus on. While the mission and vision are to provide education and opportunities to those who might otherwise not have them, the ultimate goal/aim is to increase enrollments, whatever the cost. There are no admissions standards and limited review of student progress beyond whether the student "persistently enrolls." Keywords like retention and persistence are based solely on numbers, ignoring all qualitative meaning: are students "persisting" because they're getting a financial aid check and getting 100s on every assignment regardless of effort/merit? That question is rarely asked, despite lower-level staff reporting entire course grade books that consist of nothing but 100s on every student assignment (true of a large number of courses, not just a handful). Should the retained students actually be retained? While opportunities are important, not everyone is suited for an academic environment. Often, the best service to a student is to lead them in a different direction, one that would cause the student to withdraw from the university. While that may sound negative, it is absolutely the best interest of the student. Continuing to enroll students who cannot successfully complete the coursework (because they don’t have the foundational knowledge, because they don’t speak English, etc.) is essentially stealing from those students: taking their money, but not giving them the opportunity to learn. The fact that there are absolutely no English language requirements for anyone (except international students whose highest degree came from a non-English speaking school…which is a very, very small segment of CSU’s English Language Learners) should be a giant red flag. But again, a profit-fueled company will not turn a student away, regardless of the need. Those two questions only scratch the surface of the disconnect between the company's mission and its actual business practices. The dollars and the numbers always trump the student’s needs/success. Just do a little research into the vast amount of students using cheat sites like Course Hero or boostmygrades.com and the actual quality of the education will appear as what it really is: a mirage.

The company is owned by a family, and the company touts its family atmosphere. This is often true, primarily because nepotism runs high in the company. Husbands and wives, brothers and sisters, fathers and sons, etc. often work together and influence the work environment. CSU is very much focused on "who you know" rather than "what you know." Promotions are often given based on popularity or family ties rather than based on the best person for the job. HR exists solely to maintain the status quo, not to work to make an environment that supports and encourages successful employees. For example, after several complaints regarding the air quality in part of the building (a presumed mold issue causing excessive sneezing and congestion among many employees), the HR solution was to tell employees to “buy a plant.” 

There are many "fun days" throughout the year to build the mirage of a happy family culture. Those events, while perhaps good-intentioned, often seem to be a punishment as they occur during work hours: who wants to go to work, but not work? Those who choose not to attend these events must use personal time, vacation time, or unpaid time off. An example of a recent event was a tailgate kickoff: a two-hour picnic in the middle of the day…in August…in South Alabama. After the picnic, everyone had to return to work for the rest of the day.

Regarding turnover, the numbers actually do reveal a lot. Today, there are 18 open positions posted on the University webpage. This does not include the positions only available to current employees. Each pay period, an average 5-8 new employees start. This should imply that the number of staff is growing. In fact, the number of employees has significantly decreased over the past 3 years, as the university, to save money, requires significant justification (need) to replace any vacated position. That means, on average, that more than 5-8 employees leave CSU each pay period (every two weeks). 

This company is very good at finding people's strengths; it is even better at exploiting those strengths without appropriate reward (compensation only being one type of reward lacking). Once an employee pushes back or asks for commensurate rewards, the employee becomes problematic to the university. The number of employees terminated for "not fitting in with the culture" of the university is much larger than one should expect.

review_title: Some Really Good and Some Really Bad.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Orange Beach, AL
pros:
The owners strive to keep the family culture. The time off is great. The owners allow fun days, food days, and creativity. The pay is good in SOME departments for this area. Health benefits are amazing!

The values that CSU is built on are wonderful.
cons:
I want to preface that this comes from an honest place in hoping that the company can improve. Also, throwing all management in the same pot may seem extreme and I realize that not everyone is guilty of what's stated below. Unfortunately, the majority are and as a result the culture is deeply affected.

Since the university has grown, the family culture feels fake and forced. The owners have good intentions but most of their management does not carry any of it out. The management are a bunch of suck ups. They tell the owners what they want to hear and act like a bunch of CSU family culture cheerleaders in front of them, but are completely different to their employees. The employees are rarely praised, instead we are always told what needs to improve and what we may have done wrong. Our ideas are never taken seriously or given any credit. The office politics are horrible and most of the time you feel like a child in grade school. Also, management talks about each other and other employees in front of their employees. This is very wrong and should not be happening, it also puts the employee in an uncomfortable position. 

Communication is HORRIBLE. Period.

Promotions, practices, policies, etc. are put into place on a whim without having the tools needed to successfully manage and perform the necessary tasks. This makes the lives of the employee's that do the work miserable. Then, when things don't work out and numbers aren't "what they should be" the employees are condemned. Management is always contradicting themselves and, because things are done on a whim and fail, things are always changing. This means that all the work you just did was for nothing. This happens ALL THE TIME and in the numerous departments I've worked for.

Management is not transparent by any means and rarely shows any integrity. Also, they do not stick up for their employees and nothing is ever kept in confidence (also my experience in every dept. I've worked for).

Management and HR give you the run around when you ask about a policy or pay. The policies in the Employee Handbook don't mean anything because department heads make up their own rules and explanations. HR supports management, not the employees.

The company puts on big events like Fall Bash and an annual Christmas Party. These events are amazing and I think its so wonderful that the owners want to do this for their employees. Unfortunately, a lot of the employees have bad attitudes and don't appreciate it as they should. The reason is because the true culture of CSU is lost in the office politics and the way management is to their employees on a daily basis.

review_title: My Admissions sentence was just over 3 years

Remote location.  Foley, AL isn't exactly a metropolis.  Not much going out out there.  Pensacola is the nearest "big" city.  Plan to either relocate to the middle of nowhere or drive long distances.

job_title: Supervisor in Orange Beach, AL
pros: The culture at Columbia Southern University promotes teamwork and personal growth as an employee. The university offers excellent opportunities to all employees and encourages professional development. A great place to work!
cons: Career advancement can be slow at Columbia Southern University since employee turnover is slow. Most management positions are difficult to achieve.

job_title: Academic Advisor in Orange Beach, AL
pros: They do come across with your paycheck every two weeks. Paychecks have never bounced.
cons: If you have a brain and an opinion, this is not the place for you. This is a herd of mindless sheep, and this is what is desirable to them for employees. "Cult-like" as others said is quite an accurate description. Everyone wants out of here but there just are not that many jobs in our area right now. Overloaded with work always because the employee turnover is outrageously high. They manipulate numbers to make it appear everything is okay with the place, but it isn't. In just one year, the advising center lost half its staff- people just get sick of their krap.  If you happen to be allowed into the little circle of the managers and hang out at the bar with them, then you can do whatever you want and you don't have to work, but for the other 80% of the poor suckers working here it sucks. Managers gossip and pick at employees over really petty things- they are very immature. This business does not operate by any recognized business principles- they just kind of do whatever they want when they want. No foresight here either, they make really major changes without even considering what else might happen as a result of the change. Every day of work here  is a day of hell. You will even  be told what you are allowed or not allowed to say in your personal life when it has nothing to do with the college. Also, if you are not part of the "in" group, you will be worked to death. There is no where to go here either- no advancement unless you attend their church and you manage to get into the "in group" which rarely happens for anyone. You will never get SACSCOC with the incompetent people you have running this place.

job_title: IT Professional in Orange Beach, AL
pros: The hours, management's willingness to work around your schedule and accommodate your personal life, Encouragement to better yourself, Pay increases for certifications earned and they pay for you to take the tests and give you the training material, advancement opportunities, Family atmosphere
cons: Pay could always be better, mandatory motivational meetings

job_title: Desktop Support Specialist in Orange Beach, AL
pros: CSU was a great place to work when you're looking to start your career and go back to school. You really can't go wrong with the employee benefits. 90% off is a really big deal, when you are trying to get a jump start on life. The reason why I was at CSU for so long was because of this one reason.
cons:
Everyone talks about the groups, the friends and the family that work there. In my interview I was asked if their religious beliefs would offend me, I was told not to gossip because everyone is related to everyone. Honestly I didn't give it a second thought, mostly because this was an interview, and everyone will say what they think the interviewer wants to hear to get a job.  Once i started to work there, I started to regret my decision, most of the employees are family members to each other.
. 
1. There are more meetings than any place I have ever seen. I used to work in IT and when I would need the permission of a supervisor, no one could be found because they would be at their hourly meeting followed by their lunch meeting. Don't try to interrupt their meetings either, they would get upset if you didn't ask for permission and they would get upset if you didn't get the job done, it was a lose lose situation. Fortunately I had a supervisor whom everyone "feared" and was allowed to complete the task, no matter what the consequence.

2. Managers are like that loud obnoxious spoiled kid who holds their breath until they get what they want. I had been a manger before working at CSU and I understood the value of leading a team. I have taken CSU courses on management and their own management doesn't follow their own courses! This place was "management for dummies" first time managers who demanded the world. I had to walk a manager away from my teammates cube because she made her cry. Also I am not sure what scientific report they are following, but it cannot be healthy for employee morale to move from one cube to another, literally weekly.

3. Family atmosphere. This is the same kind of atmosphere you would find from the "Children of God" cult. Never in my life had I worked for an organization where you had to pray in order to start the "Employee Day" events. It's easy if you don't want to offend anyone, and you call yourself equal opportunity, then keep it to yourself.  You couldn't leave, because "why would you leave your family?" You were made to stay outside, and celebrate in their "forced fun" activities. Look, the owners need to know, no one cares about those events. Give your people a day off and let them do their own thing. Seriously who wants to be at work and not working?

Now, you can call me an upset employee but really I followed the rules, I wasn't written up for a single thing, I had perfect attendance and was awarded for it and I was still, for whatever reason, fired. If you currently work there Alabama is a "At will" state, meaning the probationary period is only for benefits.

job_title: Student Services in Orange Beach, AL
pros: Attention to physical, mental, and emotional health of employees  is given and a holistic approach to employee satisfaction is approached by leadership; Professional development opportunities are there if you seek them out; overall work environment is inclusive and supportive of individuals needs to flourish at work.
cons: Sometimes feels like a call center rather an institution of higher learning

job_title: Travel Representative in Orange Beach, AL
pros: cant think of any to waste my time
cons: this month makes one year that i left that terrible place. i look back at it and consider it a blessing because of what they put me though. the travel rep department was not all that and they have very high turn over. i don't understand how they can continue to keep some of the people that call themselves running that department and school. i left there only make very little money but after i left, i got with a company making 3x's as much money. im doing better than them and doing what i like to do. the woman that runs that department is incompetent and very prejudice and she has her little lap dog assistant going along with it. i could care less now what they are doing because i know they are still there doing the same thing and i have moved on, fully! i have advice to anyone that wants or thinks they want to work there, DON'T. its not worth your time, effort, gas to go down there to that place they call a school.  all they are going to do is trump up lies on you to get you fired because by then you have figured out what nonsense they have going on. i figured it out the first month i was there and was continuing to look for a better job. its like a real cult there, very clanish and they think you are suppose to think and act like them to get along with the group. guess what people? everyone don't go alone with a group, some people actually think for themselves and have a life!  the people that run that department (including hr) put me though so much stuff its ridiculous. they are all kin to one another and of course being an outsider, they would not help me. even when i had proof of wrong doing in that department. i vowed never to put anyone through what they put me though if i am a director of a department. they micromanage too much for them to be a unaccrediated university. the thing is they don't understand why they can't be accrediated... i say look at how you are running your departments!

review_title: Too many chiefs and not enough indians!
job_title: Development in Orange Beach, AL
pros: you get off only 2 hours early on fridays
cons: Too much nepotism, not enough educated people work there, they are nosey and they will stab you in the back to keep their own two-bit job. Also CSU will low-ball you in pay especially if you have an advanced degree. They will not pay you what you are worth if you aren't kin to them. They want to work you like a slave for peanuts. They think if you are getting paid $30k they are to get $100k worth of work out of you, I don't work like that! I worked at least 60 hours a week and only got paid what my salary was (not knowing any better) in the beginning that the hours were long! They didn't tell me that. In their mind they thought they were doing you a favor and paying you "big money" not! I was placed in a trick bag when I transferred to another department not knowing that the managers/directors would stab me in the back and lie on me about everything. They blamed me for stealing gas! I never stole gas from them people, I have no reason too! My director even said that they believed that I paid too much for parking! Ha! you got to be kidding! i got news for her: big cities, big money! if a parking garage says its $40, its $40 dollars! I can't control that! But they used that against me again get me out. They blamed me for everything!  They talked out of two sides of their mouth, if you got $51 dollars a day to eat, you got $51 dollars! they had a problem with me eating! the write up went on and on and on. Crazy miserable people! They didn't have proof and they thought that I would sign a right up with lies! HAHA not this one. Things I didn't even know anything about. I had nothing to do with. I looked at the write up and it looks like a person in 6 or 7 years old wrote it. My 4 year old niece knows 3 languages and writes better than that. I read it to some lawyers that are working on my case now and they said it was ridiculous how an adult couldn't "so called" write up someone with no valid cause. I just laughed because it was ridiculous! And they thought I would be stupid enough to sign some mess like that. If it isn’t signed it’s not valid!  I know if they worked anywhere else, they wouldn't survive a day in a real work environment so they stay at that "school" until they retire or diie whatever comes first.  If I had known what I knew now then I would have never taken that job. I would tell anyone not to allow them to bully you into taking a job that’s fewer than 60k.Understand your supervisor will be untrained, uneducated idiots that are prejudice and can't comprehend anything especially strategic planning, training, customer service, etc. If you think differently than them, they will hate you just like they hated me. I didn't depend on my paycheck so I didn't care if I was let go or if I quit, the money was just icing on the cake. When they know you are depended on them they will treat you any kind of way. My house was paid for, my cars were paid for, and I had money in the bank before I worked there so therefore I walked out happy with no regrets. The people that work there will be in that job for the rest of their lives because they don't have the gall to go anywhere else and they have been brainwashed to think that CSU is the only gig in town. I came in the most raggedy car I could find and didn't let them ride in my car so they couldn't know my business. I wore basic clothes to work every day and I keep them out of my business and my social networking. I always heard from people off and on that the people that worked there were weird and I didn't want to believe it but now I do. They weren't going to use my expertise and capitalize on it, because they didn't pay me enough. Lastly, those folks will lie in your face in a New York minute! Grinnnnnn in your face and go back to the director / supervisor to make you look bad if they think you are a threat to them. I expect that coming from people that think that the school is the best thing since sliced bread. Its pitiful how people will do just about anything and be a "go-along-get-along" no matter if it’s a lie or if it’s the truth. Words of advice for anyone that wants to work there don't do it. If you absolutely have too, do no more than 6 months and leave! Apply for jobs 24/7 until you find something better.  I thought CSU was a good opportunity because they "sold" me on a pipe dream and a pie in the sky; But instead it was a nightmare. The most positive thing was I got my business off the ground on their dime and got the best contacts for my business and passed them on to others that may have not been able to get those contacts and utilized my knowledge, skills, and abilities to get more money while on the clock working for non-regionally accrediated CSU.
